We are considering a separate crawler to crawl these seeds. We are 
considering making the crawl very focused (seeds only or maybe a small 
number of hops out from the seeds).

Can Heritrix be configured to pause when it runs out of URIs to crawl 
instead of finishing?

If adding additional seeds via the action directory, can Heritrix be 
configured to automatically begin crawling if in this paused state?

Can an update.seeds file placed in the action directory have the format

+http://www.domain.com/some/path/to/page.html

or does it need to be in surt format?

--David

On 1/21/2012 12:22 AM, Gordon Mohr wrote:
>> 5) We are capturing tweets from twitter, harvesting the urls and want to
>> crawl those urls within 1 day of receiving the tweet. Can you recommend
>> a strategy for doing this with the 5 instances we are running?
>>
>> - Do we need to run a separate crawler dedicated to this? If so, can you
>> suggest a way to crawl out from the tweeted urls but when we get
>> additional urls from the tweets, quickly change focus to these urls
>> instead of the ones branching out. When adding urls as seeds, can you
>> set a high priority to crawl those before the discovered urls? Do you
>> recommend maybe setting up a specific crawl for these urls and then only
>> crawl a few hopes from the seeds - injecting the urls from the tweets as
>> seeds?
>
> Dedicating a special script or crawler to URIs that come from such a
> constrained source (Twitter feeds), or that need to be crawled in a
> special timeframe, or according to other special limits (fewer hops),
> could make sense.
>
> It would take some customization of the queueing-policy or 'precedence'
> features of Heritrix to allow URIs added mid-crawl to be prioritized
> above those already discovered and queued. The most simple possible
> customization might be a UriPrecedencePolicy that takes all zero-hop
> URIs (which all seeds and most direct-fed URIs would be) and gives them
> a higher precedence (lower precedence number) than all other URIs.
